poem:
### Corrections and Speed

At 600 meters:  
time twists, falters—  
knots in the raceway.  
Hodgkinson soars.

Simpson, steady  
bat slices hours—  
not "more than,"  
but enough for legends.

Errors shaved,  
truth nearly caught  
in print's haste—  
laps and hours  
revised,  
unstilled,  
but still alive in  
the paper remains.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Corrections and clarifications • A report of the Diamond League 800m race said Keely Hodgkinson “went through 800m in 85sec”; this was her time at 600m (Hodgkinson hits her stride in Lausanne to set bar for Tokyo, 21 August, p35). • Our obituary of the Australian cricketer Bob Simpson said he batted for “more than 13 hours” to make “an unbeaten 311” in 1964. In fact, it took him nearly 13 hours and he was". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
